name: src/App.js
App
description:
`App` contains the orchestration logic for the entirety of what is being displayed for a given app, including the app chrome like navigation.

App communicates these changes to {@link Component}s via events so that they may react.

The [hello-world example](https://github.com/Transmutable/bink/blob/main/examples/hello-world/site.js) has the most basic App and the [components example](https://github.com/Transmutable/bink/blob/main/examples/components/site.js) is more complex.
examples:
<caption>Set up a basic user administration page</caption>
import { AdminApp } from '{some path}/App.js'
import { UpdateBioComponent } from './UpdateBioComponent.js'
import { ResetPasswordComponent } from './ResetPasswordComponent.js'
import { UpdatePortraitComponent } from './UpdatePortraitComponent.js'
import { UserModel } from './UserModel.js'

class AdminApp extends App {
constructor(){
// Get user model (see DataObject, DataModel, and DataCollection docs)
this.dataObject = new UserModel()
this.dataObject.fetch().catch(err => { ... handle error ... })

// Set up the masthead
this._masthead = new MastheadComponent(
undefined,
{
brand: 'Your Brand',
brandAnchor: '/',
menuItems: [
{ name: 'Bio', anchor: '#' },
{ name: 'Password', anchor: '#password' },
{ name: 'Portrait', anchor: '#portrait' }
]
}	
).appendTo(this)

// Set up three sub-views with Components (see Component docs)
this._bioComponent = new UpdateBioComponent(this.dataObject).appendTo(this)
this._passwordComponent = new ResetPasswordComponent(this.dataObject).appendTo(this)
this._portraitComponent = new UpdatePortraitComponent(this.dataObject).appendTo(this)

// Set up the Router (see Router docs)
this._router = new Router()
this._router.addRoute(/^$/, 'default')
this._router.addRoute(/^password$/, 'password')
this._router.addRoute(/^portait$/, 'portrait')
router.addListener('blog-app', (routeName) => {
switch (routeName) {
case 'default':
this._bioComponent.show()
this._passwordComponent.hide()
this._portraitComponent.hide()
break
case 'password':
this._bioComponent.hide()
this._passwordComponent.show()
this._portraitComponent.hide()
break
case 'portrait'
this._bioComponent.hide()
this._passwordComponent.hide()
this._portraitComponent.show()
break
}
})
}	
}

name: append
description: Adds the childComponent's `dom` to this Component's `dom`.

return.description: this App, handy for chaining

name: removeComponent
description: Removes the childComponent's `dom` from this Component's `dom`.

return.description: this App, handy for chaining

params.name: shouldGather
params.description: true if the {@link Localizer} should be tracking translations

name: src/Component.js
Binder
description:
Binder listens for events on {@link EventHandler}s or DOM elements and changes characteristics of an HTMLElement or Component in response.
This is part of what makes a Component "reactive".

name: listenTo
description:
Listen to events from a DOM element or {@link EventHandler} in a way that they can be automatically cleaned up.

Inside of a `Component`'s implementation you should use `listenTo` instead of directly listening using `HTMLElement.addListener` or {@link EventHandler.addListener}.

The advantage of using `Component.listenTo` is that `Component` will keep track of these events and listener functions and then clean them up in {@link Component.cleanup}.
examples:
<caption>Listen to DOM element events</caption>
class MyComponent extends Component {
constructor(dataObject=null, options={}) {
super(dataObject, options)

// Listen to the Component's DOM fragment root:
this.listenTo('click', this.dom, (domClickEvent) => {
// Handle the entire Component's DOM click events
})

// Listen to events on a child DOM element
const buttonEl = dom.button('Click me').appendTo(this.dom)
this.listenTo('click', buttonEl, (ev) => {
// Handle the button's DOM click event	
})
}
}

<caption>Listen to a sub-Component's events</caption>
class AnotherComponent extends Component {
constructor(dataObject=null, options={}) {
super(dataObject, options)

this.buttonComponent = new ButtonComponent(undefined,
{ text: 'Click me' }
).appendTo(this)
this.listenTo(
ButtonComponent.ActivatedEvent,
this.buttonComponent,
(eventName) => {
// Handle the button's activated event
}
)
}
}

params.name: eventName
params.description: for DOM elements this will be a string like 'click' and for `Components` it will be a Symbol like `ButtonComponent.ActivatedEvent`

params.name: target
params.description: the object whose events should be listened to

params.name: callback
params.description: the function that is called when a matching event arrives

params.name: once
params.description: if true, the listener will be automatically removed when its first event arrives

return.description: return `this` for chaining

name: bindText
description:
Sets the `innerText` of the target DOM element to the value of dataModel.get(dataField), even as it changes.

`formatter` defaults to the identity function but can be any function that accepts the value and returns a string.

params.name: dataField
params.description: The name of the field to watch

params.name: target
params.description: The DOM element whose `innerText` will be manipulated

params.name: dataModel
params.description: defaults to this Component's `dataObject`

name: bindAttribute
description:
Sets an attribute of the target DOM element to the value of dataModel.get(dataField), even as it changes.

`formatter` defaults to the identity function but can be any function that accepts the value and returns a string.

params.name: dataField
params.description: The name of the field on the `DataModel`

params.name: target
params.description: The DOM element to manipulate

params.name: attributeName
params.description: The DOM element's attribute to change

params.name: formatter
params.description: defaults to identity (no change to field data)

name: Component
description:
`Component` contains the reactive logic for a responsive UI element.

It manages its DOM fragment based on events from DataModels and DataCollections as well as user input events.

It also tracks listeners so that on `cleanup` it can deregister itself to prevent object leaks.

Bink comes with a library of components so be sure to check the API docs before implementing a common basic view. They are also pretty good examples of how to write Components.
examples:
<caption>A toggle with a label</caption>
class BinaryComponent extends Component {
constructor(dataObject=null, options={}) {
super(dataObject, Object.assign(options, {
label: null,
dataField: null,
dom: dom.span() // Default to a `span` DOM element
})
this.addClass('binary-component')

// Check that we have the info we need
if (typeof this.options.dataField !== 'string') {
throw new Error('BinaryComponent requires a `dataField` option')
}
if (this.dataObject instanceof DataModel === false) {
throw new Error('BinaryComponent requires a DataModel')
}

// Use a few sub-Components for UI
this._labelComponent = new LabelComponent(undefined, {
text: this.options.label || lt('No label')
}).appendTo(this)

this._toggleComponent = new SwitchComponent( this.dataObject, {
dataField: this.options.dataField
}).appendTo(this)
}
}

params.name: options.dom
params.description: The HTML element that contains this Component's UI

params.name: options.anchor
params.description: A URL that to which the document will traverse if the `dom` is clicked.

params.name: options.name
params.description: If set, calls {@link Component.setName} with the value

name: dataObject
description:
`Component.dataObject` can be null or any class that extends {@link DataObject}.

By default, that's {@link DataModel} and {@link DataCollection} but coders may create their own DataObject extension.

name: cleanup
description:
Called to dispose of any resources used by this component, including any listeners added via {@link Component.listenTo}.

Extending classes *should* override and release any resources that they control.

return.description: the Component should not be used after this but the return is useful for chaining

name: dom
description:
The DOM object that contains this Component's UI.

You can override the default `dom` value from the constructor by passing an HTMLElement into the constructor's `options.dom`.
examples:
<caption>Use it like any normal DOM element</caption>
myComponent.dom.setAttribute('data-example', 'new-value')

name: anchor
description: A URL that to which the document will traverse if the `dom` is clicked, usually set via the constructor's `Option.anchor`

params.name: value
params.description: A URL string to which the document will traverse if the `dom` is clicked

name: append
description: Adds the childComponent's `dom` as a child of this Component's `dom`

return.description: returns `this` (not the child component) for chaining

name: removeComponent
description: Removes the childComponent's `dom` from this Component's `dom`

params.name: clean
params.description: if true, call {@link Component.cleanup} on the removed Component

return.description: returns `this` (not the childComponent) for chaining

name: appendTo
description: A handy method for quick creation and setting of a parent:
examples: this._fooComponent = new FooComponent().appendTo(parentComponent)

params.name: parentComponent
params.description: The component to which `this` is appended

return.description: returns `this` (not the parent component) for chaining

name: setName
description:
Sets the `name` attribute on this component's `dom.dataset` attribute.

This is optional but it can be useful during debugging.

return.description: returns `this` for chaining

name: addClass
description:
Add one or more classes to this component's dom `class` attribute without removing any existing classes.

This is optional but the best practice is to add a unique name for classes that extend `Component`.

return.description: returns `this` for chaining

name: removeClass
description: Remove one or more classes from this component's dom `class` attribute without changing other classes

return.description: returns `this` for chaining

name: hide
description: Hides the dom by adding the `hidden` class

return.description: returns `this` for chaining

name: show
description: Shows the dom by removing the `hidden` class

return.description: returns `this` for chaining

name: listenTo
description:
Listen to a DOM, {@link Component}, or {@link DataObject} event.

The nice thing about using `listenTo` instead of directly adding event listeners is that {@link Component.cleanup} will remove all of those listeners to avoid leaking this object.
examples:
this.buttonDOM = dom.button('Click me')
this.listenTo('click', this.buttonDOM, (domEvent) => { ... })

this.buttonComponent = new ButtonComponent(...).appendTo(this)
this.listenTo(ButtonComponent.ActivatedEvent, this.buttonComponent, (eventName) => { ... })

this.exampleModel = new DataModel({ someField: 42 })
this.listenTo('changed:someField', this.exampleModel, (eventName, ...params) => { ... })

params.name: once
params.description: only listen to the first event, then unbind

name: bindText
description:
Sets the `innerText` of the target DOM element to the value of `dataModel.get(dataField, '')`, even as it changes.

`formatter` defaults to the identity function but can be any function that accepts the value and returns a string.

params.name: dataField
params.description: The name of the field to watch

params.name: target
params.description: The DOM element whose `innerText` will be manipulated

params.name: dataModel
params.description: defaults to this Component's `dataObject`

name: bindAttribute
description:
Sets an attribute of the target DOM element to the value of dataModel.get(dataField), even as it changes.

`formatter` defaults to the identity function but can be any function that accepts the value and returns a string.

params.name: dataField
params.description: The name of the field on the `DataModel`

params.name: target
params.description: The DOM element to manipulate

params.name: attributeName
params.description: The DOM element's attribute to change

params.name: formatter
params.description: defaults to identity (no change to field data)

name: src/DOM.js
domElementFunction
description:
domElementFunction is the behind the scenes logic for the functions like dom.div(...)
Below you will find the loop that uses domElementFunction

name: dom
description: An object that provides helper functions that generate [HTMLElements](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLElement), usually for populating {@link Component.dom}.
examples: Text and dictionary parameters do handy things dom.a(lt('Click me'), { href: '/some-url/' }) // `Click me`

Any parameter can be a string, a dictionary, or another element dom.button( { type: 'button', class: 'my-button' }, dom.img({ src: 'image.jpg' }), lt('Click me') ) // `` dom.ul( dom.li(lt('First item')), dom.li(lt('Second item'), { class: 'selected-item' }) // Attribute dicts can be in any parameter ) //
    //
  • First Item
    • //
  • Second item
    • //

<caption>Populate a Component's UI</caption>
class MyComponent extends Component {
constructor(dataObject, options) {
super(dataObject, options)
this.dom.appendChild(dom.h1(lt('This is a heading')))
}
}

name: src/DataCollection.js
DataCollection
description:
An ordered list of DataModel instances, either locally or [fetched](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Fetch_API) from a service.

There are various ways to sort the collection, from {@link DataCollection.sort} to {@link DataCollection.keepSortedByField}.
The comparator functions used in sorting should use the same return values (e.g. -1, 0, 1) as the [Array.prototype.sort](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/sort) comparators.
examples:
<caption>Constructed with data:</caption>
this.collection = new DataCollection([
{ id: 0, title: 'first model'},
{ id: 1, title: 'second model'},
{ id: 3, title: 'third model'}
])

<caption>A custom class that is populated from a service:</caption>
class ExampleCollection extends Collection {
get url() { return '/api/examples' }
}
this.collection = new ExampleCollection()
this.collection.fetch().then(() => { ... }).catch((err) => { ... })

params.name: data
params.description: An array of data objects that are loaded into {@link DataModel}s

params.name: options.dataObject
params.description: the `class` of a `DataObject` type to use to wrap each data item in this collection

return.description: the DataObject at `index` in the internal list

throws.description: throw when index is out of range

params.name: data
params.description: the data used to create a new DataModel in this collection

params.name: options
params.description: the options passed into {@link DataModel.constructor}

return.description: returns `this` for easy chaining

name: addBatch
description: Add an array of DataObjects to the end of the collection

name: firstByField
description: Find the first DataModel with a certain field value.

params.name: dataField
params.description: The name of the DataModel field in which to look

params.name: value
params.description: The value of the field to match using `===`

return.description: The first matching DataModel or null if there is no match
returns `this` (the collection) for easy chaining

name: reset
description: Reset the state of the collection.

params.name: data
params.description: Used like the `data` parameter of the contructor to reset the state of the collection

name: sort
description: Rearranges the order of the Collection using a specific sorting algorithm

name: length
description: The number of data items in this collection

name: src/DataModel.js
DataModel
description: Holds a map of <string, value> pairs, sometimes fetched from or sent to a back-end server.
examples:
<caption>Directly loading data</caption>
this.model = new DataModel({ id: 42, something: 'different' })
this.model.get('id') // returns 42
this.model.get('something') // returns 'different'
this.model.get('bogus', 'default') // returns 'default'

<caption>Fetching data from a service</caption>
class ExampleModel extends DataModel {
get url() { return '/api/example' }
}
this.model = new ExampleModel()
this.model.fetch().then(() => { ... }).catch(err => { ... })

params.name: options.fieldDataObjects
params.description: a map of dataField (string) to DataObject (class), used to create sub-objects in this Model's data

name: cleanup
description: See {@link DataObject.cleanup} for details.

return.description: true if this model contains a field with the name of `dataField`

name: get
description: Find a value held within this DataModel.

params.name: defaultValue
params.description: a value to return if the field value is `undefined`, `null`, or the empty string

return.description: may be native types or, if mapped by options.fieldDataObjects, another DataObject

name: getFirst
description: Return the first value that this `DataModel.has` or 'undefined' if none are found

return.description: may be undefined, native types, or (if mapped by options.fieldDataObjects) another DataObject

name: set
description: Set a key/value pair

params.name: value
params.description: the new value of the field

name: setBatch
description:
Set a group of values. The 'values' parameter should be an object that works in for(key in values) loops like a dictionary: {}
If a key is in options.fieldDataObjects then the value will be used to contruct a DataObject and that will be the saved value.

name: increment
description: Add a value to a field, creating the value if necessary

return.description: the new value of the field

name: delete
description: Calls the DELETE method on the service resource

params.name: obj
params.description: the value to compare to `this` or `this.get('id')`

name: src/DataObject.js
DataObject
description:
`DataObject` is the abstract base class for {@link DataModel} and {@link DataCollection}.

This holds the event handling and the generic function of fetching data from a remote service.

params.name: options
params.description: Not used by DataObject but helpful for extending classes

name: cleanedUp
description: True after {@link DataObject.cleanup} has been called.

name: cleanup
description: When models are no longer needed `cleanup` should be called to release resources like event listeners.

return.description: returns `this` for easy chaining

name: isNew
description: True until a fetch (even a failed fetch) returns

name: url
description: The URL (relative or full) as a string for the endpoint used by {@link DataObject.fetch}.

name: reset
description: Clear out old data and set it to data, should trigger a 'reset' event

name: parse
description: Extending classes can override this to parse the data received via a fetch

name: equals
description: Extending classes can override this to allow less strict equality

name: onFirstReset
description: If already reset, immediately call callback, otherwise wait until the first reset and then call callback

name: fetchOptions
description:
Extending classes can override this to add headers, methods, etc to the fetch call

By default the only fetch option set is `credentials: same-origin'.

name: fetch
description:
Ask the server for data for this model or collection.

Depends on {@link DataObject.url}, {@link DataObject.parse} and {@link DataObject.reset}.

name: _innerFetch
description:
This can be overridden to use something other than `window.fetch` during internal testing.

Extending classes should override `fetch` if they're not using `window.fetch`

name: fetchAll
description:
Fetch each DataObject and then wait for them all to return

This resolves when the fetches complete, regardless of whether they succeed or fail.
examples:
this.model = new DataModel()
this.collection = new DataCollection()
DataObject.fetchAll(model, collection).then((mod, col) => { ... })

name: save
description:
Tell the server to create (POST) or update (PUT) this model or collection.

If {@link DataObject.isNew} is true it will POST, otherwise it will PUT.

name: delete
description: Call `DELETE` on this object's remote endpoint.

name: src/EventHandler.js
EventHandler
description: The base class that implements event distribution for classes like {@link Component}, {@link DataModel}, and {@link DataCollection}.

name: trigger
description: Send an event to listeners

params.name: eventName
params.description: an identifier for the event like 'changed:fieldName' or 'deleted'

params.name: params
params.description: the parameters handed to the listeners

name: addListener
description:
Adds a listener callback for a given event name.

If you pass `EventHandler.ALL_EVENTS` then the callback will receive all events, regardless of name.

params.name: eventName
params.description: a string or Symbol indicating the event to watch

params.name: callback
params.description: often includes more parameters that are specific to the event

params.name: once
params.description: If true then the listener is removed after receiving one event

name: removeListener
description: Removes reference to a specific listener.

params.name: callback
params.description: the function originally passed into {@link EventhHandler.addListener}.

name: cleanup
description:
Removes all references to listener callbacks.

This should be called by extending classes.

return.description: returns `this` for chaining

name: src/Localizer.js
Localizer
description:
`Localizer` provides the functionality necessary to:

- pick a string translation based on language
- format dates based on locale and time zone

In most cases you should use {@link Localizer.Singleton} instead of creating your own Localizer.
todo: detect language, locale, and timezone
load translations

name: constructor
description: In most cases you should use {@link Localizer.Singleton} instead of creating your own Localizer.

name: defaultLocales
description: A list of [BCP 47](https://tools.ietf.org/html/bcp47) locale strings from [navigator](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/NavigatorLanguage/languages).

name: gathering
description: This should NOT be turned on in production because it continuously grows in memory.

params.name: val
params.description: true if the Localizer should accumulate strings to translate

return.description: the translated string

name: dateFieldOrder
description: Different locales order their dates in various ways: mm/dd/yyyy or yyyy.mm.dd or 2012년 12월 20일 목요일

return.description: the date in locale form

params.name: long
params.description: true if the month should be long form

return.description: the date in locale form

params.name: long
params.description: true if the month should be long form

return.description: the date and time in locale form

name: Singleton
description: In almost all cases you should use this singleton instead of constructing your own {@link Localizer}.
examples: Localizer.Singleton.formatDate(new Date())

name: Translation
description: Translation holds a map of source phrases to translated phrases in a given language

name: lt
description: A shorthand function for getting a translation

params.name: key
params.description: the source phrase, like 'Hello!'

params.name: defaultValue
params.description: the value to return if there is no translation

return.description: a translation, like '¡Hola!'

name: ld
description: A shorthand function for getting a localized date

return.description: a localized string representing the date

name: ldt
description: A shorthand function for getting a localized date and time

return.description: a localized string representing the date and time

name: ldo
description: A shorthand function for getting a localized date or time string using your own options

return.description: a localized string representing the date

name: src/MockService.js
src/Router.js
Router
description:
Router maps [`window.history`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/history) events and URL path fragments (the part after the `#` in https://example.com/path#one-two-three) to events.

This is usually used by an {@link App} to show and hide {@link Component}s based on the URL.
examples:
<caption>routing `/^blog\/([0-9]+)\/app\/([0-9a-z]+)$/` to an event with parameters for blog and app IDs</caption>
let router = new Router()

// Set up a couple of routes, each with a URL matching regexs and a route name

// matches http://<domain>/<path> and http://<domain>/<path>#
router.addRoute(/^$/, 'default')

// matches http://<domain>/<path>#blog/1123/app/abc-123
router.addRoute(/^blog\/([0-9]+)\/app\/([0-9a-z\-]+)$/, 'blog-app')

// Listen for the route
router.addListener('blog-app', (routeName, hash, ...regexMatches, ...parameters) => {
// If this was an event triggered by routing to #blog/1123/app/abc-123 then:
// `routeName` would be 'blog-app'
// `hash` would be 'blog/1123/app/abc-123'
// `regexMatches` would be ['1123', 'abc-123']
// `parameters` is empty in this example but could be any number of extra items in the route (see `addRoute`)
})

router.start()

params.name: regex
params.description: The regular expression that matches the incoming hash changes

params.name: eventName
params.description: The event name used when triggering

params.name: parameters
params.description: Parameters passed without modification to listeners after the event name and matches

name: start
description: This must be called in order to start routing.

return.description: true if this route matches a given path

name: src/components/atoms/AudioComponent.js
AudioComponent
description:
AudioComponent contains a sound source and shows an icon.

If you want to display controls, use {AudioPlayerComponent}.
todo: Actually display the icon

params.name: options.audio
params.description: a URL to an audio file

params.name: options.audioDOM
params.description: an HTML `audio` element to use as a source

name: src/components/atoms/ButtonComponent.js
ButtonComponent
description: ButtonComponent displays a button, natch.

name: src/components/atoms/HeadingComponent.js
HeadingComponent
description: HeadingComponent represents a title or heading made up only of text.
examples:
<caption>Use static text</caption>
const headingComponent = new HeadingComponent(undefined, {
text: 'Welcome to Bink'
})

<caption>Use bound text</caption>
const headingComponent = new HeadingComponent(yourDataModel, {
dataField: 'title'
})

params.name: options
params.description: See the {@link TextComponent.constructor} options, including dynamic text formatting.

name: src/components/atoms/ImageComponent.js
ImageComponent
description: ImageComponent handles the display of a single image.
examples:
<caption>Use a static URL</caption>
const component = new ImageComponent(undefined, {
image: '/static/image.png'
})

<caption>Use a bound URL</caption>
const component = new ImageComponent(myDataModel, {
dataField: 'image'
})

params.name: options
params.description: see the {@link Component} options

params.name: options.image
params.description: the URL of an image

params.name: options.dataField
params.description: the name of the field in dataObject that holds the URL to the image

params.name: value
params.description: the image URL

name: src/components/atoms/LabelComponent.js
LabelComponent
description: LabelComponent displays a single line of text
examples:
<caption>Use static text</caption>
const component = new LabelComponent(undefined, {
text: 'Example'
})

<caption>Use bound text</caption>
const component = new LabelComponent(yourDataModel, {
dataField: 'title'
})

params.name: options
params.description: See the {@link TextComponent.constructor} options, including dynamic text formatting.

name: src/components/atoms/LinkComponent.js
LinkComponent
description:
LinkComponent displays an `a` element containing static text or text that is bound to a field in the dataObject.

This class is meant to be used where you'd include an inline text link. See the {@link Component.constructor}'s `option.anchor` parameter if you want click events on a Component's DOM element to trigger navigation.
examples:
<caption>Use static text</caption>
const component = new LinkComponent(undefined, {
text: 'Click me',
url: '/some-other-page/'
})

<caption>Use bound text</caption>
const component = new LinkComponent(yourDataModel, {
dataField: 'name',
url: '#some-other-view'
})

params.name: options
params.description: See the {@link TextComponent.constructor} options, including dynamic text formatting.

params.name: options.url
params.description: The URL to which the link should anchor. This can conflict with the `options.anchor` passed to Component.constructor.

name: src/components/atoms/MultiComponent.js
MultiComponent
description: MultiComponent holds a set of {@link Component}s and shows one at a time.

params.name: index
params.description: The index in this.components of the Component to show

params.name: component
params.description: The component to show. It will be added to this.components if it isn't already in there

name: src/components/atoms/ProgressComponent.js
ProgressComponent
description: ProgressComponent tracks change of a process and displays a progress bar
examples:
<caption>Watch a DataModel's field</caption>
const progressComponent = new ProgressComponent(myDataModel, {
dataField: 'completion'
})
todo: make it watch a field on the dataObject with a filter function that maps to 'starting'|'complete'|'failed'|[0,1]

params.name: options.dataField
params.description: a DataModel field to track with this progress readout

name: value
description: value - float from 0 to 1

name: value
description: value - float from 0 to 1

name: src/components/atoms/SelectionComponent.js
SelectionComponent
description: SelectionComponent offers the user a set of choices for single or multiple selection.

name: src/components/atoms/SliderComponent.js
SliderComponent
description: SliderComponent gives the user the ability to choose from a range of values by dragging a handle from side to side of a bar.
todo: Allow min and max values other than 0 and 1
Add granularity or "snapping" for example only allowing tenths.

params.name: val
params.description: a number to set the slider value which will be clamped in the minValue and maxValue inclusive range

return.description: The fraction between 0 and 1 inclusive that the current value is between the minValue and maxValue

params.name: fraction
params.description: a number between 0 and 1

name: src/components/atoms/SwitchComponent.js
SwitchComponent
description:
SwitchComponent gives the user the ability to flip a switch.
The switch may be on/off or momentary with push-to-break or push-to-make options.
examples:
<caption>Allow the user to change a boolean data field</caption>
const switchComponent = new SwitchComponent(myDataModel, {
dataField: 'activated'
})
todo: Add a Bink event on switch change (DataModel 'changed:fieldName' events work, of course)

params.name: options.dataField
params.description: a field in dataObject that this switch should reflect and control

name: src/components/atoms/TextComponent.js
TextComponent
description: TextComponent holds a string which may include paragraphs but not other media.
examples:
<caption>Show static text</caption>
const textComponent = new TextComponent(undefined, {
text: 'Static text goes here'
})

<caption>Show dynamically bound text</caption>
const textComponent = new TextComponent(myDataModel, {
dataField: 'title'
})

<caption>Show dynamically bound and formatted text</caption>
// Displays either 'Is active' or 'Is not active', depending on the data field
const textComponent = new TextComponent(myDataModel, {
dataField: 'isActive', // a boolean field
dataFieldFormatter: (value) => { return value === true ? 'Is active' : 'Is not active' }
})

params.name: options
params.description: see the {@link Component} options

params.name: options.text
params.description: the initial text shown in the heading

params.name: options.dataField
params.description: a field in the dataObject to bind to as the text

params.name: options.dataFieldFormatter
params.description: a function that takes in a dataField value and returns a string

name: src/components/atoms/TextInputComponent.js
TextInputComponent
description: TextInputComponent shows the user a field or area in which to enter text.
examples:
<caption>Set `TextInputComponent.text` to user's input (no DataModel)</caption>
const component = new TextInputComponent(undefined, {
text: 'Starting text',
placeholder: 'Enter some text here' // Shown when no text had been entered
})
// Listen for text changes
component.listenTo(TextInputComponent.TextChangeEvent, (eventName, textValue) => {
console.log('Text was input', textValue)
})

<caption>Bind text input to a DataModel field</caption>
const component = new TextInputComponent(myDataModel, {
textField: 'biography',
placeholder: 'Tell us who you are', // Shown when no text had been entered
submitOnEnter: true
})
// Listen for text submission, usually by pressing the 'Enter' key
component.listenTo(TextInputComponent.TextSubmitEvent, (eventName, newValue) => {
console.log('New text was submitted', newValue)
})

params.name: options.text
params.description: initial text

params.name: options.dataField
params.description: a field on the dataObject on which to bind

params.name: options.placeholder
params.description: text to show when the input is empty

params.name: options.submitOnEnter
params.description: trigger a submit event on `enter` keyUp event

name: src/components/atoms/ToggleComponent.js
ToggleComponent
description:
ToggleComponent shows a triangle and represents an open or closed state.
The user can change the toggle state by clicking the toggle.
todo: Allow the use of different emoji or even images

return.description: true if the toggle is open

name: open
description: Sets the toggle open

name: close
description: Sets the toggle closed

params.name: open
params.description: whether the toggle should be open or not

name: src/components/atoms/VideoComponent.js
VideoComponent
description:
VideoComponent displays a single video.

If you want to display controls, use {@link VideoPlayerComponent}.

params.name: options.preview
params.description: the URL to a still image to show until the user plays the video

params.name: options.video
params.description: the URL to a video

params.name: options.mimeType
params.description: the mimeType for the video

unknown.tagValue: {float} the time at the current frame in seconds

return.description: the total duration of the video in seconds or 0 if it isn't yet loaded

name: play
description: Play the video, loading it if it isn't already.

name: pause
description: Pause the video, loading it if it isn't already.

name: toggle
description: Call this to switch between playing and paused states.

name: loadVideo
description: Call this to start loading the video

name: setSourceAttributes
description: Sets the attributes on the `video` HTMLElement.

params.name: url
params.description: the relative or full URL to the video

params.name: mimeType
params.description: a mime type like 'video/mp4'

name: src/components/index.js
content:
import { AudioComponent } from './atoms/AudioComponent.js'
import { ButtonComponent } from './atoms/ButtonComponent.js'
import { HeadingComponent } from './atoms/HeadingComponent.js'
import { ImageComponent } from './atoms/ImageComponent.js'
import { LabelComponent } from './atoms/LabelComponent.js'
import { LinkComponent } from './atoms/LinkComponent.js'
import { MultiComponent } from './atoms/MultiComponent.js'
import { ProgressComponent } from './atoms/ProgressComponent.js'
import { SelectionComponent } from './atoms/SelectionComponent.js'
import { SliderComponent } from './atoms/SliderComponent.js'
import { SwitchComponent } from './atoms/SwitchComponent.js'
import { TextComponent } from './atoms/TextComponent.js'
import { TextInputComponent } from './atoms/TextInputComponent.js'
import { ToggleComponent } from './atoms/ToggleComponent.js'
import { VideoComponent } from './atoms/VideoComponent.js'

import { AudioPlayerComponent } from './molecules/AudioPlayerComponent.js'
import { CardComponent } from './molecules/CardComponent.js'
import {
	FormComponent,
	FormFieldComponent,
	DateFieldComponent,
	SwitchFieldComponent,
	SelectionFieldComponent,
	TextInputFieldComponent,
} from './molecules/FormComponent.js'
import { ImageCardComponent } from './molecules/ImageCardComponent.js'
import { MenuComponent } from './molecules/MenuComponent.js'
import { PaginationComponent } from './molecules/PaginationComponent.js'
import { ToolTipComponent } from './molecules/ToolTipComponent.js'
import { VideoPlayerComponent } from './molecules/VideoPlayerComponent.js'
import { WaitComponent } from './molecules/WaitComponent.js'

import { CollectionComponent } from './organisms/CollectionComponent.js'
import { MastheadComponent } from './organisms/MastheadComponent.js'
import { MediaGridComponent } from './organisms/MediaGridComponent.js'

export {
	// atoms
	AudioComponent,
	ButtonComponent,
	HeadingComponent,
	ImageComponent,
	LabelComponent,
	LinkComponent,
	MultiComponent,
	ProgressComponent,
	SelectionComponent,
	SliderComponent,
	SwitchComponent,
	TextComponent,
	TextInputComponent,
	ToggleComponent,
	VideoComponent,
	// molecules
	AudioPlayerComponent,
	CardComponent,
	FormComponent,
	FormFieldComponent,
	DateFieldComponent,
	SwitchFieldComponent,
	SelectionFieldComponent,
	TextInputFieldComponent,
	ImageCardComponent,
	MenuComponent,
	PaginationComponent,
	ToolTipComponent,
	VideoPlayerComponent,
	WaitComponent,
	// organisms
	CollectionComponent,
	MastheadComponent,
	MediaGridComponent,
}

name: src/components/molecules/AudioPlayerComponent.js
AudioPlayerComponent
description: AudioPlayerComponent shows an {@link AudioComponent} along with play/pause controls.
examples: new AudioPlayerComponent(undefined, { audio: '/static/audio.wav' })
todo: Add an optional progress/shuttle component
Make this reactive to a DataModel

params.name: options.audio
params.description: a URL to an audio file

params.name: options.audioDOM
params.description: an HTML `audio` element to use as a source

name: src/components/molecules/CardComponent.js
CardComponent
description:
CardComponent displays a piece of content like an image or video along with its title and caption.

This is often used in a {@link CollectionComponent} or a {@link MediaGridComponent} to display a collection of cards.

{@link ImageCardComponent} is an example of extending `CardComponent` for a specific media type.

The three child `Component`s are available via getters for `mainComponent`, `titleComponent`, and `captionComponent`.

name: _mainComponent
description: the main content, like an image or video

name: mainComponent
description: The {@link Component} in which we display the main content, like an image or video

name: titleComponent
description: The {@link Component} in which we display the title of the card

name: captionComponent
description: The {@link Component} in which we display the caption of the card

name: src/components/molecules/FormComponent.js
FormComponent
description:
FormComponent is meant to be used to modify values of a {@link DataModel}.

FormComponent holds:

- a heading that titles the form
- a set of {@link FormFieldComponent}s that provide input UI for fields in the DataModel
todo: Create a PasswordInputFieldComponent
Create a form error display element and per-field error display elements
Add a `WaitComponent` to show while submitting the form
Add default Submit/Reset/Clear controls

params.name: options
params.description: see the {@Component} for inherited options

params.name: options.heading
params.description: the heading text for this form

name: FormFieldComponent
description:
FormFieldComponent is the base {@link Component} for fields in a {@link FormComponent}.

It only contains a {@link LabelComponent} as direct sub-classes (listed above) will add input `Component`s.

If you have a unique field type then this is the class to extend with your custom UI.

name: constructor
todo: Make the label reactive to a DataModel field

params.name: options.label
params.description: the display text for this input field used in a LabelComponent

params.name: options.dataField
params.description: the name of the {@link DataModel} field for this form element

name: DateFieldComponent
description: DateFieldComponent provides day, month, and year input for use in a {@link FormComponent}.

params.name: options
params.description: see {@link FormFieldComponent} for more options

return.description: the date specified in the input fields or null if it is not parsed

name: SwitchFieldComponent
description: SwitchFieldComponent shows a {@link SwitchComponent} to toggle a boolean field value in a {@link FormComponent}.

params.name: options
params.description: see {@link FormFieldComponent} for more options

name: SelectionFieldComponent
description: SelectionFieldComponent provides a dropdown selector for use in {@link FormComponent}s.

params.name: options
params.description: see {@link FormFieldComponent} for more options (like `label`)

params.name: options.items
params.description: an array of [display name, value] to be used as choices in the selector

name: TextInputFieldComponent
description: TextInputFieldComponent provides a text field, natch

params.name: options
params.description: see {@link FormFieldComponent} for more options

params.name: options.placeholder
params.description: the text displayed in the field when there is no value text

name: src/components/molecules/ImageCardComponent.js
ImageCardComponent
description:
ImageCardComponent is a {@link CardComponent} extension that shows a single image and metadata.
It shows the image along with an optional title and caption from the `CardComponent`.
examples:
<caption>Use a DataModel to drive the image card.</caption>
const model = new DataModel({
image: '//static/image.png',
name: 'Great Image',
description: 'You will love it'
})

const imageCardComponent = new ImageCardComponent(model, {
dataField: 'image',
titleField: 'name',
captionField: 'description'
})

params.name: options.image
params.description: a URL to an image

params.name: options.dataField
params.description: the field name in the DataObject that holds the URL to an image

params.name: options.title
params.description: a string to use as a title

params.name: options.titleField
params.description: the field name in the DataObject that holds the title of the image

params.name: options.captionField
params.description: the field name in the dataObject that holds the caption

name: src/components/molecules/MenuComponent.js
MenuComponent
description:
MenuComponent holds a set of menu item {@link Component}s and a {@link ToggleComponent} to show and hide the menu.

This class is often used as a base class and in the extending constructor it loads its menu items but it's also possible to use it directly (see below).
examples:
<caption>Directly create a three item menu</caption>
const menuComponent = new MenuComponent()
menuComponent.appendMenuItem(new MyMenuItemComponent(...))
menuComponent.appendMenuItem(new MyMenuItemComponent(...))
menuComponent.appendMenuItem(new MyMenuItemComponent(...))

menuComponent.addListener(MenuComponent.SelectedEvent, (eventName, menuComponent, selectedIndex) => {
const menuItemComponent = menuComponent.menuItems[selectedIndex]
})

menuComponent.addListener(ToggleComponent.ToggleEvent, (eventName, menuComponent, isOpen) => {
// react to the change here
})

params.name: index
params.description: the index of the menu item to set selected

name: open
description: Open the toggle component

name: close
description: Close the toggle component

name: toggle
description: Toggle the toggle component open or closed

params.name: component
params.description: A menu item Component to add to the menu

params.name: index
params.description: the index of the menu item to toggle

params.name: visible
params.description: whether to show or hide the menu item

name: src/components/molecules/PaginationComponent.js
PaginationComponent
description: PaginationComponent shows controls for moving forward and back in list or collection.const
todo: Make this watch a DataCollection or other DataObject that has a pagination interface and events

name: src/components/molecules/ToolTipComponent.js
ToolTipComponent
description:
ToolTipComponent shows a Component next to another Component

If possible, it's better to use the [title](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Global_attributes/title) element attribute, but this is useful for tooltips with more than text.
todo: Replace the hacky 'X' close widget with something better

name: src/components/molecules/VideoPlayerComponent.js
VideoPlayerComponent
description: VideoPlayerComponent shows a {@link VideoComponent} with play/pause and shuttle controls.

params.name: options.video
params.description: a URL to a video

params.name: options.mimeType
params.description: the MIME type for the video, like 'video/mp4'

params.name: url
params.description: the relative or full URL to the video

params.name: mimeType
params.description: a mime type like 'video/mp4'

name: src/components/molecules/WaitComponent.js
WaitComponent
description: WaitComponent shows a spinner to reassure the user that a process is happening.
todo: Make this watch a DataObject and react to events like saving or fetching and update

name: state
description:
Will be one of:

- WaitComponent.NOTHING_HAPPENING
- WaitComponent.PROCESSING
- WaitComponent.FAILED
- WaitComponent.SUCCEEDED

name: state
description:
Must be one of:

- WaitComponent.NOTHING_HAPPENING
- WaitComponent.PROCESSING
- WaitComponent.FAILED
- WaitComponent.SUCCEEDED

name: src/components/organisms/CollectionComponent.js
CollectionComponent
description: CollectionComponent provides a generic list UI for {@link DataCollection}s.
examples:
<caption>Use the DefaultItemComponent</caption>
const myCollection = new DataCollection(...snip...)
const collectionComponent = new CollectionComponent(myCollection)

<caption>Use a custom item Component</caption>
const myCollection = new DataCollection(...snip...)
class CustomItemComponent extends Component {
constructor(dataObject=null, options={}) {
// Set up your item UI here
}
}
const collectionComponent = new CollectionComponent(myCollection, {
itemComponent: CustomItemComponent, // the class, not an instance
itemOptions: { someKey: 'someValue' } // passed as options to item component constructors
})

<caption>Responding to clicks on items</caption>
const myCollection = new DataCollection(...snip...)
const collectionComponent = new CollectionComponent(myCollection, {
onClick: (dataObject) => {
// Do something with the DataObject (probably a DataModel) whose item has been clicked
}
})
todo: Add rearrangement via drag and drop
Add pagination support once {@link DataCollection} supports it

params.name: options.itemComponent
params.description: a Component class used to render each item in this list

params.name: options.itemOptions
params.description: a set of options to pass to each item Component

params.name: options.onClick
params.description: a function to call with the dataObject whose item Component is clicked

return.description: indexed `Component` or `null` if index is out of bounds

name: filter
description:
Call this to change whether item Components are show or hidden based on the result of a function.

A common pattern is to listen to Collection events like fetched or reset and then re-run a filter.

params.name: filterFn
params.description: returns true if the DataObject's item Component should be shown

name: DefaultItemComponent
description:
DefaultItemComponent is used by {@link CollectionComponent} if no 'itemComponent' option is passed.

The only thing in this {@link Component} is a {@link LabelComponent} with the first field that exists of: 'title', 'name', or 'text'.

You'll usually want to pass an `itemComponent` option to `CollectionComponent` to present a custom item.

name: src/components/organisms/MastheadComponent.js
MastheadComponent
description:
MastheadComponent contains:
- a brand Component (a {@link HeadingComponent} by default)
- a navigation {@link MenuComponent}

This is usually placed at the top of a page to show the site brand and a navigation menu. Then a {@link Router} is used to respond to document.location changes.

params.name: options.brand
params.description: the main title

params.name: options.brandAnchor
params.description: an activation URL for the brand HeadingComponent

name: src/components/organisms/MediaGridComponent.js
MediaGridComponent
description:
MediaGridComponent creates a CSS grid of {@link CardComponent}s like {@link ImageCardComponent} or custom components that you make for other media like videos, audio tracks, etc.

It uses a {@link CollectionComponent} with the `itemComponent` option set to a {@link CardComponent} like {@link ImageCardComponent}.
todo: Support pagination once 'CollectionComponent' supports it

params.name: options.itemComponent
params.description: the options object to pass to the item class constructor

params.name: options.itemOptions
params.description: the Component **class** used for each item in the DataCollection

name: src/index.js
content:
import App from './App.js'
import dom from './DOM.js'
import Router from './Router.js'
import Component from './Component.js'
import DataModel from './DataModel.js'
import Localizer from './Localizer.js'
import { throttle } from './throttle.js'
import DataObject from './DataObject.js'
import MockService from './MockService.js'
import DataCollection from './DataCollection.js'

/**
 * This is used by rollup to create a handy all-in-one ES module
 */

export { App, dom, Router, throttle, Component, DataModel, Localizer, DataObject, MockService, DataCollection }

name: src/throttle.js
throttle
description:
`throttle` will rate limit a function call.

This code is cribbed from https://github.com/jashkenas/underscore
examples:
<caption>Throttling rendering info</caption>

var count = 0 // This will be incremented in every animation frame

// We want to call this in every animation frame but only run it once a second (1000 ms)
const throttledDebug = throttle(() => { 
console.log('Render count', count)
}, 1000)

// This is the function that is called in every animation frame
function render() {
count += 1
throttledDebug() // Called every frame but run only once a second
window.requestAnimationFrame(render)
}
window.requestAnimationFrame(render)

params.name: wait
params.description: the minimum number of milliseconds between calls.

params.name: leading
params.description: if true, the first call to the throttled function is immediately called.

params.name: trailing
params.description: if true, once the wait time has passed the function is called.

return.description: the throttled function

name: throttledConsoleLog
description: A handy utility function for throttling console logging to once per second

params.name: params
params.description: The parameters to pass to `console.log`

content:
# Bink

[Bink](https://github.com/Transmutable/bink) is a sleek and reactive framework for Javascript-driven web pages.

It:
- Has no dependencies
- Is written in modern Javascript
- Can be taught in less than an hour
- Enables localization and internationalization
- Provides reactive components with data binding of data models and collections

Choose Bink when:

- Your web app is inherently dynamic
- You don't need to support retired browsers like IE
- You worry about the fragility of dependency trees
- You're unhappy with ever-moving targets like React
- Your implementation team knows Javascript
- Your leadership is comfortable working without social proof

Do not choose Bink when:

- You're making a web page that can be static
- You need to support IE and other retired browsers
- You can live with the fragility of dependency trees
- You're happy within churning ecosystems like React's
- Your implementation team needs markup abstractions like JSX
- Your leadership is rewarded for "[choosing IBM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fear,_uncertainty,_and_doubt)".

## Overview of Bink

The [API docs](https://transmutable.github.io/bink/api/) have a lot of info and example code but in general: 

A web page's script element instantiates a Bink [`App`](https://transmutable.github.io/bink/api/class/src/App.js~App.html) that coordinates dynamic user interface elements made up of [`Component`](https://transmutable.github.io/bink/api/class/src/Component.js~Component.html)s that reactively update the DOM based on information and events in [`DataModel`](https://transmutable.github.io/bink/api/class/src/DataModel.js~DataModel.html)s and [`DataCollection`](https://transmutable.github.io/bink/api/class/src/DataCollection.js~DataCollection.html)s as well as events from user actions.

### Examples on Glitch

These examples are [in the repo](https://github.com/Transmutable/bink/tree/main/examples) but here they are as Glitch projects for immediate satisfaction. Glitch lets you view the code and then remix it with no fuss.

- [Hello, world](https://glitch.com/edit/#!/northern-tricky-brook) is a bare bones page but it does demonstrate a custom App and a custom Component.
- [Components](https://glitch.com/edit/#!/valiant-agate-acoustic) shows every [Component](https://transmutable.github.io/bink/api/class/src/Component.js~Component.html)s that is included with Bink and a bit more complex use of [App](https://transmutable.github.io/bink/api/class/src/App.js~App.html).

### A quick code sample from [Hello World](https://github.com/Transmutable/bink/tree/main/examples/hello-world)

Here's a small snippet of code to give you a flavor of Bink.


```javascript
/*
This Component simply asks to be clicked and then changes its message when that happens.
*/
class ClickMeButton extends ButtonComponent {
	constructor(dataObject=null, options={}) {
		super(dataObject, Object.assign({
			text: lt('Click me') // `lt` is the `Localizer` translation method
		}, options))

		// Add to the existing `class` attribute on `this.dom`. This is good practice but still optional.
		this.addClass('click-me-button-component')

		// Setting the name sets `this.dom.data[name]` for use during debugging. This is optional but handy.
		this.setName('ClickMeButtonComponent')

		// ButtonComponent has an event type, ActivatedEvent that we listen to
		this.listenTo(ButtonComponent.ActivatedEvent, this, (eventName) => {
			this.text = lt('You Clicked Me')
		})
		// Because we used `this.listenTo` the event listener will be automatically cleaned up when `Component.cleanup` is called.
	}
}

/*
App instances run the entire single page app by coordinating DataObjects and Components.

This App simply loads a HeadingComponent and the custom ClickMeButton from above
*/
class SplashApp extends App {
	constructor(options={}) {
		super(options)

		// A Component renders something to the DOM, in this case an 'h1' element
		this._headingComponent = new HeadingComponent(undefined, {
			text: lt('Hello, world')
		}).appendTo(this)

		this._clickMeButton = new ClickMeButton().appendTo(this)
	}
}
```

### What `App` provides:

- Page-level orchestration of views
- URL routing
- User input context

### What `Component` provides:

- Manage DOM fragments in views
- Provide business logic
- Track and clean up listeners and data binding

Bink ships with a library of `Component`s.

### What `DataModel` and `DataCollection` provide:

The code snippet above doesn't use dynamic data so it doesn't need `DataModel` or `DataCollection`. Here's what those classes do:

- Manage a shared data structure for key/value maps (models) and ordered lists (collections)
- Wrap logic for communicating with services like remote web APIs or local storage
- Provide data change events so that the UI can react

## Use Bink in your projects

Bink is designed to be easy to use without an ecosystem like [npm]( https://www.npmjs.com/).

The quickest way to get started is to download the latest source code release zip from the [Releases page](https://github.com/Transmutable/bink/releases) and copy the `/src/` and `/style/` directories into your project's doc root. That's how the examples mentioned above work. ☝️

If you are stuck using `npm` (perhaps via [yarn](https://yarnpkg.com/)) and need to use Bink that way (dang it) then it's available as [@transmutable/bink]( https://www.npmjs.com/package/@transmutable/bink).

## Who made Bink?

Bink is the result of two+ decades of work on and with browsers by [Trevor Flowers](https://trevor.smith.name/) who leads [Transmutable](https://transmutable.com/) and is [@TrevorFSmith](https://twitter.com/trevorfsmith) on Twitter.
name: ./README.md
package.json
